title: Krauthammer on 'Special Report' on President Trump Travel Ban, Fallout
text:
// Executive Order 
As a federal appellate court listened to oral arguments in a lawsuit over President Donald Trumpâ€™s travel and refugee ban, Charles Krauthammer explained why he thinks it was unnecessary for Trump to restrict immigration from seven countries with predominantly Muslim populations in the first place. 
On "Special Report" tonight, Krauthammer argued the whole thing is a "kabuki" to make us feel safer from terrorism. 
He pointed out that in the 15 years since 9/11, the U.S. hasn't been attacked by even one national from the seven countries restricted by   - Iraq, Syria, Sudan, Iran, Somalia, Libya and Yemen. Read Full Article 
"I'm not against tightening the vetting. We should," Krauthammer said. "But I think it was unnecessary to order an immediate suspension for 90 days, as if there was an imminent threat that hordes of Yemenis and Somalis were about to board airplanes and attack the United States." 
He said that barring people doctors, students and grandmothers from entering the U.S. was what caused the backlash to Trump's order, and it hurt the administration's argument. 
Krauthammer noted that polls show the American public has changed its opinion on admitting Syrian refugees into the U.S., with a majority of people now in favor of the refugee resettlement program. 
"I think it's a direct result of the fact that this was an unnecessary overshoot," Krauthammer said. "Yes, tighten up the vetting. But there was no reason to suspend the visits of people who were already in the air."
